Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-performance nanowire cathodes with stabilized microporous tunnels for Na-ion batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rechargeable batteries help to enable a sustainable energy future through the storage and demand-matched delivery of electricity generated from fluctuating renewable sources such as wind or sun. Currently, lithium-ion batteries offer the best performance in terms of capacity, power delivery, and longevity. However, lithium is a limited resource with respect to both its total supply in the Earth's crust and its geographic availability. Rechargeable batteries which use sodium ions instead of lithium ions for storing charge address the possibility of lithium scarcity in the future, because sodium is a very abundant element. However, sodium ions are much larger ion than lithium ions, and this large size creates a variety of operational problems within a rechargeable battery, particularly swelling of the battery electrode during charging and discharging. Through nanotechnology-based approach, this project will develop new cathodes for sodium-ion batteries using hollow nanowires which confine the sodium ions within a tunnel structure. The nanowires will be made of magnesium oxide with tunnel diameters of about 2 nanometers. The key innovation is that by confining the sodium ions, within the tunnel, the swelling can be controlled and storage capacity can be increased simultaneously. The scientific outcomes of this project can be used to help research with other future metal ion battery systems based on magnesium, aluminum and potassium, where similar issues might occur. The educational activities associated with this project include outreach to school-age children from under-represented groups in engineering through the Richmond Area Program for Minorities in Engineering, the Philadelphia Science Festival, and the Annual Young Women?s conference.

The goal of this research is to improve the mechanical stability and electrochemical energy storage capacity of sodium-ion batteries by tuning of the pore geometry and ionic content of microporous, sodium-ion intercalation electrodes. The key hypothesis is that both swelling and storage capacity can be controlled by carrying out the sodium-ion intercalation process within tunnel-structured, sodium-stabilized manganese oxide nanowires. These nanowires contain one-dimensional microporous tunnels forming defined diffusion paths that facilitate reversible sodium ion intercalation. The research plan has three objectives. The first objective is to synthesize magnesium oxide nanowire cathodes that contain one-dimensional, microporous tunnels with defined sodium ion diffusion channel dimensions, and then evaluate their electrochemical performance and mechanical strength. These measurements will be realized through bulk-scale electrochemical characterization and single nanowire-based nanoelectrochemical probing and mechanical degradation testing. The second objective is to improve the specific capacity within the nanowire channels by increasing the sodium content within the microporous tunnels through chemical routes. Through the first and second objectives, the top performing materials will be identified that maximize capacity, mechanical stability, and life cycle. The third objective is to improve electrochemical storage capacity and mechanical stability during repeated charge/discharge cycles through dopant-induced crystal stabilization of the nanowire electrode materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A traditional rechargeable battery sustains its repeated charging and discharging processes through the reversible insertion and extraction of an underlying charge carrying ion within its constituent electrode materials. The current market for rechargeable batteries is dominated by the lithium ion (Li-ion) technology, which employ lithium ions as the primary charge carrying species. This collaborative project was motivated by the global need to advance alternate battery chemistries, which can alleviate the supply constraints associated with sourcing lithium for Li-ion batteries, particularly for large-format grid storage and transportation applications. Emphasis in this project was placed, in substantial part, on solutions of relevance to the sodium-ion (Na-ion) system due to the abundant availability of sodium at a low cost. In addition, sodium offers a safer alternative during battery storage and transportation, since these batteries can be safely discharged to zero charge without negatively affecting the active materials. However, current electrodes in sodium-ion batteries experience capacity limitations and cycle-life limiting mechanical degradation during the reversible insertion and extraction of sodium ions. This is due, in large part, to the larger size of the sodium ions in comparison to their lithium counterpart. This project explored solutions to this technological barrier through the synthesis and testing of novel, microporous manganese dioxide based cathodes, apart from advancing new methodologies for testing battery electrodes at the nanoscale. An important aspect of these materials is their synthesis and use in a nanowire geometry, which are cylindrical elements with ultra-small diameters of less than 50 nanometers (1 nanometer is equal to a billionth in fraction of a meter), and with lengths that are typically 2 orders of magnitude larger than their diameters. Furthermore, these manganese dioxide nano-cylinders contained an array of “tunnels” or porous channels of controllable cross-sectional sizes along their length. These tunnels provide pathways for the placement and transport of charge carrying ions during their insertion and extraction processes. While electrode material synthesis and its testing in conventional battery configurations was performed by a collaborating partner at Drexel University, the effort at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) focused on testing the mechanical and structural stability of these electrode materials at the single-particle level through new chip-based, nanoscopic material testing platforms.

During the tenure of this project, these single-particle enabled research activities delivered several important contributions. Considerable effort  was spent on studying the mechanical properties and stabilization strategies for electrode-relevant tunnel manganese dioxide nanoceramics. While these ceramics at the bulk-scale undergo brittle fracture when subjected to mechanical loads that exceed its material strength, this project revealed for the first time that nanostructuring presents avenues for their mechanical stabilization via controlled engineering of microstructural inhomogeneity, (i.e., through non-homogenous tunnel sizes and composition). A number of chip-based advanced characterization methodologies were also developed and deployed for studying the mechanical, microstructural, and electrochemical properties of these materials at the single-particle level. This includes a new multi-microscopy approach that allows for both, mechanical testing and atomic-resolution imaging of the samples by engineering their compatibility with atomic force and transmission electron microscopes. Another capability involved the creation and testing of nanoelectrochemical cells on silicon chips for studying their performance in true battery-like configurations while maintaining an ability to investigate electrode performance through post-electrochemistry advanced microscopy. Apart from sodium-ion cells, substantial effort was also devoted to studying Magnesium-ion insertion into the tunnel manganese oxide nanoelectrodes, since Magnesium offers another abundant and safer alternative to Li-ion batteries. In addition, this project demonstrated electric-field driven assembly methodologies to assemble nanomaterials into their mechanical and electrical testing platforms. These activities delivered new insights for achieving assembly of single isolated nanowires from powdered agglomerates of these wires in billions, which could be leveraged for building nanodevices in diverse applications that range from sensors to actuators and nanoelectronics.

In the end, this project resulted in developing new characterization technology, new understanding of coupled-physics phenomena, and new simulation tools for investigating materials at the nanoscale. The project resulted in multiple journal publications and trained graduate students in interdisciplinary skills involving material mechanics, battery electrochemistry, nanoassembly, chip-based nanofabrication, and advanced microscopy.
